Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Metagenomic analysis of geminiviruses in insect vectors from the South Pacific Islands

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research

Through the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes (EAPSI) program I had the opportunity to conduct a research project with Dr. Arvind Varsani at the University of Canterbury in Christchurch, New Zealand. Dr. Varsani is an evolutionary virologist and his expertise has resulted in the discovery and isolation of new geminiviruses, which are among the most detrimental emerging plant pathogens worldwide due their impacts on staple food crops (e.g. maize). The objective of my project was to collect insect samples from the South Pacific Islands of Tonga to identify viruses of agricultural relevance carried by these vectors in a region where geminiviruses have been understudied. Several insect vectors, such as whiteflies, are an important transmission mechanism for geminiviruses. The feeding behavior of these insects may result in the exchange of virus strains between cultivated and unmanaged areas which can potentially lead to the emergence of new recombinant virulent strains. This study aimed to investigate the diversity of viruses found in insects capitalizing upon their ability to “sample” viruses from many plants over space and time.

                  

The viral community in insects was explored by purifying viral particles from insect homogenates and sequencing the DNA extracted from purified viruses. Viruses found in different archived insect samples, including aphids, whiteflies and dragonflies, were analyzed while working in Dr. Varsani’s lab. Although dragonflies do not transmit plant viruses as they only feed on other insects, they are top predators in the insect world and, thus, may provide insights into viruses that affect and/or thrive in insect populations. During a 10-day field trip to the Kingdom of Tonga several insect vectors were collected and archived for future study including whiteflies, aphids, and plant hoppers.

 

One of the highlights of this study was the discovery of a novel virus, Dragonfly cyclovirus (DfCyV), in dragonflies. DfCyV is the first virus sequenced from dragonflies, and also represents the first circular, single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) viral species detected in invertebrates. DfCyV is related to circoviruses, which are known bird and mammal pathogens, and its discovery may help elucidate the evolutionary history of these viruses.  The results of the DfCyV study have been published in the Journal of General Virology. In addition to the discovery of a new virus, we successfully developed and applied a method to investigate single-stranded DNA viruses (e.g. geminiviruses) found in different insect samples using rolling circle amplification. The developed methods will allow plant pathologists and entomologists to detect and study ssDNA viruses transmitted by insect vectors using simple methods.

 

Education and outreach

As part of the EAPSI research project we visited the South Pacific Islands of Tonga and interacted with officials from the Tonga Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries (MAFF). The involvement of MAFF officials in the project was critical to access different farms for sample collection and learn about Tongan agriculture. During our field trip, we also had the opportunity to visit Vava’u High School and talk to students from intermediate and high school levels about plant pathology and college education. Our interaction with MAFF, teachers, students, and the community resulted in a successful field trip and the interest of Tongans in our work.
